content:
I'm sorry BlackFich, I'll have to "delete" the puzzle because it has been accepted by mistake. It means that it won't be shown in the community puzzles section. However this contribution will still exist. So I advise you to create a new one and update it using the precious advice of moderators here.
Sorry about this.

This puzzle looked tedious at first sight, but was finally pretty interesting. Some remarks follow.

First, the tests could be renamed "Figure 1", "Figure 2", ... instead of "xxx-1", "xxx-2", ...

Then, the validating tests 1and 2 seem more complex than the corresponding training one. Some syllogisms in the validating tests don't correspond to any of the 4 figures, while there are no such case in the training tests.

Finally, in "Validate xxx-1", there is a test for figure 4 (3rd: all p are m and all m are s therefore all s are p), which is misleading.

Fixed erroneous exemple for {{not}} keyword
Fixed result of invalid syllogism in validator 3

The not keyword may only appear with a some keyword (ie : "some boat have no sails", "some apples are green")

I don't get this line. The examples don't use "not" at all. Also the "no sails" is confusing in its usage of the "no" keyword (presumably not a keyword in this instance).

Your third test case in Validate xxx-1 seems wrong to me.
all m are p and all s are m therefore all p are s
or
all dogs are animals and all dalmatians are dogs therefore all animals are dalmatians
I think it should be invalid.

Apart from that, this looks nice.
Input format updated

I have modified the input as follow :

Line 1 : [[n]] number of lines to read
next [[n]] lines : [[syllogism]]

where : 
[[syllogysm]] = [[major premise]] {{and}} [[minor premise]] {{therefore}} [[conclusion]]
[[premise]]/[[conclusion]] = {{all|none|some}} [[subjet]] [[verb]] [{{not}}] [[predicate]]

Does this make more sens to you ?
I think this would allow to keep the logic behind the grouping of the tests, and also make it easier for people to read the input. However this would put a bit more work for them on the parsing.

i've seen haskell people complain that such "keep reading and processing inputs until an indicator" code is hard to do in it, but i wouldn't really know. it is unusual for codingame puzzles, though.

i dont remember the max number of test cases you can define. if you can define 10 ide and 10 validation cases, i'd recommend to split your cases as if each blank line you have currently actually starts a new case (by my count then you'll have 9+9 cases, so theres room even for 1 more).

so each case has N statements and M conclusions, and you can input N M on line 1

Instead of a "end" string, why not use a int variable as the first line to define the number of the next lines ?

I don't know if it was supposed to be desired but I think it could be  more suitable for all languages

Why don't you give a unique set of premises/conclusion for each case ?
It would be more understable to me.

This is my first submission. 

I'm open to all remarks to improve it, especially for the description of the input.

Thanks

The idea is that given 2 premises, conclusions can be valid or invalid. Having only one complete syllogism per test case would make it easier to bypass the validators since it's only a true/false answer per test. Hence the idea of having several conclusions for each pair of premises.
Also each test case (and validators) test for a given figure of syllogisms

Indeed I did wonder about it as well.
Basically I want to have a variable number of syllogism in a given test each with a variable number of valid/invalid conclusions  (they test the same "figure" but different "moods") .

I did tried something like this:
2  // number of syllogisms
Premise 1 of Syllogism 1
Premise 2 of Syllogism 1
3 // number of conclusions for sylogism 1
Conclusion 1 of Syllogism 1
Conclusion 2 of Syllogism 1
Conclusion 3 of Syllogism 1
Premise 1 of Syllogism 2
Premise 2 of Syllogism 2
1 // number of conclusions for sylogism 2
Conclusion 1 of Syllogism 2

But I found it cumbersome. Also one only needs to store the 2 premises and the current conclusion. So It can be read sequencially and stored in 3 variables. No need to preallocate more than that

Another solution could be to have 1 simple syllogism (2 premises 1 conclusion) per test, and have many tests and validators to cover more mood/figures combinations.

What do you suggest would be best ?

oh wait, so N is always 2? cool, even less work then :p
aren't there interesting cases that can be built by giving more than 2 statements to work with tho?

alternatively, if given exactly 2 statements, isn't it possible to just ask for all true conclusions that can be derived from them?
I agree with this. I also believe that "all m are p and all s are m therefore all p are s" should be INVALID.

I've fix the exemples for the keyword {{not}} to this :
 "some boat have sails", "some apples are not green"
Thanks for your interest, I'll rename the test as you proposed andI'll check the validators
Indeed, I had a flaw in the identification of the figure. Should be better now (I've fixed the solution as well)

Okay... But now I'm getting a failure on xxx-3:

all squares are rectangles and all squares are rhombuses therefore some rectangles are rhombuses

Your test says this is INVALID, but it should be valid. (MaP.MaS -> PiS, Darapti AAI-3)

Also, in Validate xxx-3:

all M are P and all M are S therefore some P are S

Same pattern.

Also validate XXX-2: all P are M and some S are not M therefore some P are M
I'd think that  all P are M => some P are M. If not, could you clarify that in the question?
Yes, I was actually wondering about that but forgot to mention it. It's something my own code doesn't currently account for, but probably should.

Having more than one premise could be done indeed, but maybe in an advanced version of this puzzle as it is a bit more complicated.

As for making the input more predictable it can be done as well.

It would be nice to have some feedback of Haskell people
There is no test cases limit btw

ok Shoko

As for giving only the valid answer to a given syllogism, there are only 24 valid syllogism out of the 256 possible ones ...
